thread.title: Stocks post record close as Trump hints at major tax change
thread.title_full: Stocks post record close as Trump hints at major tax change

author: Fred Imbert
title: Stocks post record close as Trump hints at major tax change
text:
Stocks post record close as Trump hints at major tax change CNBC 1 hr ago Fred Imbert Click to expand Replay Video Why has the stock market rally stalled? From an improving economy that's already priced in to President Trump's focus on immigration, Christine Romans explains why the stock market rally has stalled. CNN Money Weak peso helps tequila giant Jose Cuervo go public Becle, parent company of the world largest tequila producer, Jose Cuervo of Mexico, is expected to raise $770 million through its public offering as the falling peso has supported its sales in foreign markets. Photo: Reuters The Wall Street Journal. Trump meets with airlines CNBC's Phil LeBeau reports ahead of the meeting between airline CEOs and President Donald Trump at the White House. CNBC SETTINGS OFF HD HQ SD LO Closing Bell Exchange: Market desperate for corporate tax reform CNBC See more videos SHARE SHARE TWEET SHARE EMAIL What to watch next Why has the stock market rally stalled? CNN Money 1:29 Weak peso helps tequila giant Jose Cuervo go public The Wall Street Journal. 1:02 Trump meets with airlines CNBC 2:00 How do fake news sites make money? BBC News 1:13 Honoured Apple CEO takes aim at Trump Reuters 1:31 Beautiful beaches that are ridiculously expensive GOBankingRates 1:06 This is the world's most expensive chocolate bar CNBC 0:39 How much is the first lady's 'brand' worth? CNN Money 2:51 What affect will Trump's travel ban have on the tourism industry? Wochit Business 0:35 Meet the forgotten founder of Apple who once owned 10% of the company Business Insider 4:28 Trump says Nordstrom treated Ivanka unfairly CNBC 1:25 Republican lawmaker proposes bill to abolish EPA Fox Business 2:23 China's deserted docks The Wall Street Journal. 2:20 5 states where taxes are rising Kiplinger 1:17 Twitter takes steps to subdue online trolls Newsy 0:32 Top 10 employee benefits and perks for 2017, according to Glassdoor TheWrap 1:50 UP NEXT Stocks rallied to record highs Thursday after President Donald Trump said he will give an announcement regarding taxes in the next few weeks.
"Lowering the overall tax burden on American business is big league ... that's coming along very well. We're way ahead of schedule, I believe. And we're going to announce something I would say over the next two or three weeks that will be phenomenal in terms of tax," Trump said in a meeting with U.S. airline executives.
The Dow ended 118 points higher, with Goldman Sachs contributing the most gains. The S&P 500 added 0.58 percent, with financials rising 1.4 percent, hitting a new all-time high. The Nasdaq also rose 0.58 percent to a new high.
"It's almost a resumption of the Trump trade," said Matt Weller, a senior market analyst at Faraday Research. "In his acceptance speech, Trump talked about infrastructure and deregulation, but in recent weeks he'd gotten away from that. This is sort of reigniting those animal spirits."
"I think it's a combination of investors feeling more confident that some tax package will get worked on. But I think that we also have lower interest rates recently and solid earnings," said Kate Warne, an investment strategist at Edward Jones.
However, " just because he says there will be an announcement doesn't mean he will agree with Congress," said Jeremy Klein, chief market strategist at FBN Securities. "It's very low volume. It's pretty quiet and there is a very persistent buyer out there pushing the market higher."
Equities rose broadly after Trump's election but have mostly traded sideways this year as investors look for clues about the administration's plans on corporate tax cuts, deregulation and government spending.
"Basically, the market is stuck in a tight trading range, and it's unlikely we'll see a catalyst to take us out of it," said Peter Cardillo, chief market economist at First Standard Financial. "Political worries are the factor keeping the market in this range."
"Remove that, and the market would be up 3-to-4 percent," he said.
The S&P 500 traded within a 1 percent range for the 38th consecutive session Thursday, its longest streak on record, according to data dating back to 1978. The index hasn't seen a 1 percent move, in either direction, since Dec. 7.
"The SPX has been digesting its gains in a consolidation phase near its highs. Breakouts have outnumbered breakdowns in a reflection of healthy market breadth, or participation," said Katie Stockton, chief technical strategist at BTIG, in a note.
The economic calendar was thin Thursday, with only two major reports on hand. Weekly jobless claims fell by 12,000 to 234,000, below a consensus estimate of 250,000. Wholesale trade data for December showed a 1 percent increase on inventories.
Meanwhile, St. Louis Federal Reserve President James Bullard said U.S. interest rates can remain low throughout at least 2017, with no clear sense yet of whether the new Trump administration's policies will touch off higher inflation or growth.
U.S. Treasurys fell Thursday after a 30-year bonds sale, with the benchmark 10-year note yield rising to 2.39 percent and the short-term two-year note yield hovering around 1.18 percent. The 30-year bond yielded 3.016 percent.
Overseas, European equities traded broadly higher, but French yields hit a two-week low amid growing political risk as far-right presidential candidate Marine Le Pen gains more traction.
In an interview with The Economist, the head of sovereign ratings at Standard & Poor's said Le Pen's debt plan for France would trigger a default.
"Investors are looking at French bond and equity markets closely and we think, a rating cut could stimulate a serious tumult in this space. We would expect the CAC40 to sell if there is a rating cut and investors could favour the German equity market," said Naeem Aslam, chief market strategist, in a note. He also said that Moody's, another rating agency, could downgrade France's debt.
